Abstract: Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII) plays a pivotal role in the regulation of calcium homeostasis and signaling pathways in the heart, making it a critical factor in the pathogenesis of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). This review focuses on the emerging evidence that positions CaMKII as a promising therapeutic target for treating heart failure and arrhythmias, among other CVDs. By modulating calcium handling, CaMKII influences cardiac contractility, electrical activity, and structural remodeling. Dysregulation of CaMKII activity has been implicated in the progression of heart failure and the development of arrhythmias, highlighting its potential as a target for pharmacological intervention. Recent advances in understanding the molecular mechanisms of CaMKII activation and its downstream effects have paved the way for the development of novel therapeutic strategies aimed at inhibiting CaMKII activity. This abstract underscores the importance of further research into CaMKII inhibitors as a means to mitigate the burden of cardiovascular diseases.
